1.e: Converting to better class of apartments
1.c: Factory smoke.

areaDesc.5: Older area in conversion to apartments, but the tone is being kepy up.

1.c: No restirctions. Too far from business centers. Cheaper class of people.

areaDesc.5: This area is about half-way between Hammond and Gary proper, five miles from each town, Construction mixed with small houses worth $1,000 up to better homes worth $3,500. Some few are worth $4,500 to $5,000.

1.c: Age and obsolescense. Cheap construction. Industrial fumes and smoke.

areaDesc.5: Surrounded by industry and railroads. About half of the homes are heated by stoves.

1.c: Uncertain restrictions

areaDesc.5: Railroad junctions and switching yards. Homes are the railroad men's bungalows and cottages. This descriptionnapplies to both Griffith and Dyer.

1.c: Some factory smoke.
1.b: Restrictions. Schools, transportation, Country Club and Park.

areaDesc.5: These three spots are newer than Area A-1 and just as highly restricted. They are farther out and slightly less accessible.

6.1: HAMMOND. Northern spot known as "Woodmar" lies in Hammond, the two other spots lie outside the city.

1.c: Uncertain restrictions.

areaDesc.5: Workingmen's village. Gardens with the homes.
New area of common labor. Owner built houses-- No planning. No facilities. Just big boxes.

1.c: Mixed structures. Summer cottages adn permanent homes.
1.a: Sand dunes. Hills and hollows. It cost $2,000 to level some lots.

b.1: frame- a few Br Veneer bungalows

areaDesc.5: Resort on the sand dunes. Very rough topography. Summer cottages mixed with permanent homes. A few structures up to $15,000 in value. Mortgage money is available only to the best names.

1.c: Factory smoke.

areaDesc.5: Excellent neighborhood for a middle class people. Uniform development. It is locally believed that the railroad yards are to be removed.

6.1: HAMMOND: the southern extremity is outside the city-- that is, below the River

1.c: Some smoke from the factories.

areaDesc.5: Best area in hammond.

6.1: HAMMOND, Inc. to the River. Munster township south of the River.

1.c: Factory smoke, Uncertain restrictions.

areaDesc.5: Fair neighborhood of alien skilled labor. Thinly settled.

1.c: Factory smoke.

areaDesc.5: Alien and negro common labor.

1.c: Factory and railroad smoke. Old fashioned houses.
1.b: Near work. Schools and transportation. Park.

areaDesc.5: Southern part borders on a "B" or "Blue" rating. Substantial old families. The extreme eastern tip is a U.S. Housing Community (World War Homes). The Treasury Department is trying to sell locally 57 mortgages believed to have face values at from $4M to $6M. Recent appraisals of these same properties are reported at from $1,500 to $3,300.

1.c: Factory smoke.

areaDesc.5: Outlying and close to industry. Workmen's homes.

1.c: Platted and sold, but not developed. No sewers, gas, water, or streets.
1.b: Resttricted. Near schools. Has Browadwat frontage. Close to Area A-6.

areaDesc.5: Probably 20 houses in the 16 blocks. Houses range in value from $5,500 to $7,000. One house in the area (on Monroe Street) is worth $10,000.

1.c: Factory fumes and dirt.

areaDesc.5: Neighborhood undesirable-- aliens and negroes.

1.c: Factory dirt; fumes and smoke.
Obsolete. Type of population. Cheap construction.

areaDesc.5: In the west spot-- single, frame bungalows, worth $1,000 to 1,500 predominate, renting at $8 to $12.

6.1: EAST CHICAGO, Indiana. in that section called INDIANA HARBOR

1.c: Fumes and smoke-- factory dirt.

a.2: South of 141st St One family units

areaDesc.5: South 141st St.: 2-story bricks, one-family units, predominate with a rating that would justify a "B" but for the definite trend of less desireables from the north. South of 140th St. and east of Main St. there is a development of Inland Steel Company duplexes, average value $7M to 8M, frame structures.

6.1: EAST CHICAGO-- in that part known as Indiana Harbor

1.c: Age and obsolescence. Type of population.

a.1: Conglomerate: singles, two-flats, stores and apartments

areaDesc.5: Sales prices refer to single family homes; rentals to dwelling units of all sorts. Good neighborhood twenty years ago; over-run by Mexican and negroes.

6.1: EAST CHICAGO, Indiana called INDIANA HARBOR, Indiana

1.c: Age and obsolescence. Cheap construction. Alien population.
1.b: Close to work. Schools and transportation.

areaDesc.5: Alien of low standard of living. Cheap foreign labor.

6.1: PARTLY NORTH HAMMOND and PARTLY WHITING, Indiana

1.c: Industrial smoke and fumes (Lever Bros. soap factory.)

d.1: 1/3 in good repair 2/3 need slight repairs

areaDesc.5: FHA guarantees some loans here at 80 percent. More in demand as to rentals. Many people rent here who would not but in this location.

1.c: Fumes and smoke. Adjacent to poor neighborhood.

d.1: 1/3 in good repair 2/3 need slight repairs

areaDesc.5: FHA guarantees 80 percent in this area on new houses. Newer and more substantial than Area C-2, except the expensive houses in Area C-2. Good area for workingmen's homes. In Areas C-1, C-2 and C-3 the influence of Standard Oil Company is felt. Community center built and bank losses were lessened by the Oil Company.

6.1: NORTH HAMMOND and east part of WHITING; the part that lies in Hammond is called "Robertsdale."

1.c: Fumes and smoke from industry and railroads.

d.1: 1/3 in good repair 2/3 need repairs slightly

areaDesc.5: Better development than C-1, but older. Numbers of old families in homes with reproduction cost of $25 M to $40 M. Sales and rental schedule given do not include these expensive homes.

6.1: PARTY NORTH HAMMOND and PARTLY WHITING; the part which lies in Hammond is called "Robertsdales."

1.c: Railroad adn industrial influences. No restrictions.

areaDesc.5: Sparsely settled; cheap shacks.

1.c: No restrictions. Bordered by negro area to the eat.

areaDesc.5: This is an area older than Gary proper. On Ellsworth and Marshall from 13th to 15th Streets are two to three-family flats. Active selling area for past twp years due to new school. Widely mixed area as to values-- a $2,000 house next to a $5,000 house. In 1929 new apartments on Fifth Avenue in Area A-4 took away tennants leaving the neighborhood a poor reputation for rentals.

1.c: Age and obsolescense. Mixed type of structures: singles, double, apartments-- stores with flats above, etc.
1.b: Schools and transportation. Fairly close to work.

areaDesc.5: An old mixed area formerly alien. Foreigners now being crowded out by negroes--all classes of undesirable, tenderloin, etc. Wholesale groceries, packing companies, etc.

1.c: Railroad and negro area to the east and south.
1.b: Convenient to work. Schools and transportation. There is some control over the area by teh Gary Land Company (U.S. Steel Corporation.)

areaDesc.5: A few 3 tp 6-flat buildings. Building and loan associations will lend here. Insurance companies are more reluctant. Buildings are of good construction, nearly 100 percent brick veneer.

1.c: Railroad and negro area to the east and south.
1.b: Convenient to work. Schools and transportation. There is some control over the area by the Gary Land Company (U.S Steel Corporation.)

areaDesc.5: A few three to six-flat buildings. Building and loan associations will lend here. Insurance companies are more reluctant. Buildings are of good construction, nearly 100 percent are of brick veneer. This area is very similar to that of Area C-18.

1.c: Lacks transportation.

areaDesc.5: Approved FHA area. Some resort properties along the river.

1.c: Lacks school and transportation facilities. Difficult to get water even at 200 feet.

areaDesc.5: Unrestricted area of cheap homes for alien labor-- A town of probably 400 people.

1.c: Railroad and factory soot and smoke.

areaDesc.5: An old congested area, a few doubles and a few six- apartment units. Nearly all are frame. Lenders are reluctant to go into this area.

1.b: Restrictions. Schools and transportation. Nice class of Polish homes.

areaDesc.5: Complete community of the more prosperous type of Polish people with their own Church, schools, etc.

1.c: Unrestricted.
1.b: Schools and transportation. feree of industry.

areaDesc.5: Approved FHA area. On the south side of Riverside Drive there are homes up to $15,000. Newer houses have raised teh current average value above the 1929 level.
Approved FHA area. This area is similar to Area B-12 except for the houses along Riverside Drive.

1.c: Railroad dirt, soot and smoke. Cinder streets. Some parts (east and south) use septic tanks.
1.b: Transportation, schools; near industry. City sidewalks, gas, water and sewers.

areaDesc.5: Development started too late. West side fairly well developed. East side almost wholly undeveloped.

1.c: Age

areaDesc.5: Central portion around the retail area is older than the city of Gary proper.

6.1: GARY, Indiana. Former town of MILLER now Gary's Tenth Ward

1.c: Railroad and industrial smoke and soot.

areaDesc.5: This area is similar to Area C-12, both being a part of the original Gary Land Company (U.S. Steel Corporation) tract. The Land Company still owns 545 homes in the two areas. The same description applies, and lenders are reluctant to go into this area. Areas: A-3, A-4, B-3, C-12 and C-13 are the entire original Gary Land Company tract (U.S. Steel Corporation.) There are a small number of duplexes and multiple units in the area.

1.c: Average age 20 years.
1.a: Flat. Shade trees-- planted trees 20-years old.

2.a: Mill superintendents and high salaried people

areaDesc.5: Adjoins a nice park on the east. Homes are 20 years old, but well equipped-- considerable remodeling going on. Just about the center (tyler Street) is a Catholic Church and schools.

1.c: Factory smoke.
1.b: Restricted. Best transportation and schools. Single family homes except  in Fifth Avenue which is restricted to apartment units, runnning up to 8-12 and 20-30 families.

areaDesc.5: No forced selling during the depression years. Houses now selling at just about reproduction cost less depreciation. few if any offered for sale.

1.c: Close to industrial area. Factory smoke.
1.b: Restrictions. Schools adn transportation are good.

areaDesc.5: Very much the same as Area A-4, but slightly cheaper and slightly more people were forced to sell than in Area A-4. All other characteristics the same.

1.b: Schools and transportation. Free from railroad and industrial influences.

areaDesc.5: The setting is pretty. Bungalows, with a few two stories, in heavily shaded area. Lots available at $500 to $700 for 40 x 125' lots. Sewers, paving, gas and lights are all in.

1.c: Railroads.

areaDesc.5: Building and loan money and some F.H.A. money available in this area. Otherwise money is scarce. Somewhat of a seperate community--with its own stores, theatres, etc. on Browadway.

1.b: Schools and transportation. Free from railroad and industrial influences.

areaDesc.5: Bungalow type of single unit predominates,--few two story structures. All city facilities.

6.2: Bungalow type of single unit predominates,--few two story structures. All city facilities.

1.c: No streets west of Pierce Street.

areaDesc.5: Good location for medium priced houses.

2.a: Tradesmen and skilled labor from the mills

areaDesc.5: Restrictions lower, and construction cheaper than in Area A-5 just to the north. Not so much pride of ownership.

1.b: Schools, transportation; free from railroad and industrial influences.

areaDesc.5: Quite the same as area A-6 except it is completly built of cheaper structures.

1.d: 60% east of Harrison St., 5% west of Harrison St.
1.c: None

areaDesc.5: This area should continue to improve; free from industrial and railroad influences. Park to the north. Modern structures-- up-to-date bungalows, for higher priced labor and for professionals not of the very first flight.

1.b: Restricted. Free of railroad and industrial influences. Good schools and transportation.

areaDesc.5: There are two houses as cheap as $7,500 and one at $40,000. The area is regarded by some people as teh very best in Gary because of the freedom from railroad and industrial influences. Others like Area A-4 because of its proximity to the center of the city.

1.c: No restrictions.
1.b: Remote from industry, transportation and schools.

areaDesc.5: Good location for cheap homes. General construction only fair through the area.

6.1: East of Mississippi outside of Gary- lying partly in East Gary and partly in Hobart. GARY, Indiana

1.c: Nickel Plate Railroad.

2.a: Business men, steel mill foremen, etc.

areaDesc.5: This is a community of the upper class of retail merchants and minor executives of the steel mills. People who can afford to move away from the railroad and industrial influences of Gary. Both sides of Garfield Street are particularly desireable.

1.c: Age and obsolescence.

a.1: One family units, big old type.

areaDesc.5: In and between the big old houses there are four-room, stove- heated frames, without basements. Average of 25 years, $1,750 in value.
